evidence.dc:description: Immunocytochemisty/immunohistochemistry of teased rat sciatic nerves show localization of GJB1 to myelinating Schwann cells/ glia. A small amount if also expressed in neurons.

dc:source.dc:abstract: We have examined the expression of a gap junction protein, connexin32 (Cx32), in Schwann cells and oligodendrocytes. In peripheral nerve, Cx32 is found in the paranodal myelin loops and Schmidt-Lanterman incisures of myelinating Schwann cells, and the levels of Cx32 protein and mRNA change in parallel with those of other myelin-related genes during development, Wallerian degeneration, and axonal regeneration. In the central nervous system, Cx32 is found in oligodendrocytes and their processes, but not in compact myelin, and the levels of Cx32 protein and mRNA increase during development in parallel with those of the other myelin genes. Thus, Cx32 is expressed as part of the myelinating phenotype of both Schwann cells and oligodendrocytes, indicating that this gap junction protein plays in important role in the biology of myelin-forming cells.
dc:source.dc:creator: Scherer SS
dc:source.dc:title: Connexin32 is a myelin-related protein in the PNS and CNS.

evidence.rdfs:label: GJB1 localizes to Schmidt-Lantermann incisors and paranodes

evidence.dc:description: The paper shows not only specific localization GJB1 to glia. In addition, it indicates that the expression of GJB1 is increased in myelinating glia, and that GJB1 expression is regulated by myelination and factors governing myelination. They went on to show the temporal expression of GJB1 by IMS and western blot, therefore the score was increased from default.

Formation of Schmidt-Lantermann incisures is important for the formation and stablization of myelin, as disruption has been shown to lead to dysmyelination. GJB1 is a gap junction protein that allows for stabilized cell-cell contact and helps to allow transfer of cell signaling molecules.
evidence.rdfs:label: GJB1 regulates myelination in the PNS and CNS

evidence.dc:description: HeLa cells are naturally deficient in connexion 32 (GJB1). Expression of wild type GJB1 showed formation of gap junctions, whilst expressing of the C60F, V139M, and R215W CMT variants showed little to no formation of gap junctions. This reduction in junction formation was not a result of reduced protein expression, as western blots confirmed equal levels of expression. Furthermore, when the C60F, V139M, and R215W variants were co-transfected with wild-type GJB1, the mutants were able to inhibit the ability of wild type GJB1 to form junctions, thus demonstrating a dominant negative effect.

dc:source.dc:abstract: We have characterized the function of connexin (Cx) 32 gene mutations found in X-linked dominant Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease with respect to their ability to form functional gap junctions among themselves and to inactivate wild-type Cx32 by a dominant negative mechanism. We prepared four types of Cx32 mutant cDNAs and transfected them into HeLa cells, which do not show detectable levels of gap junctional intercellular communication (GJIC), nor expression of any connexins examined. Cells transfected with the wild-type Cx32 gene, but not those transfected with three different base substitution mutations (i.e. Cys 60 to Phe, Val 139 to Met, and Arg 215 to Trp), restored GJIC. Unexpectedly, in cells transfected with a nonsense mutant at codon 220, there was also restored GJIC. When we double-transfected these mutant constructs into the HeLa cells that had already been transfected with the wild-type Cx32 gene and thus were GJIC proficient, three base substitution mutants inhibited GJIC, suggesting that these three mutants can eliminate the function of wild-type Cx32 in a dominant negative manner. The nonsense mutation at codon 220 did not show such a dominant negative effect. Since both mutant and wild-type Cx32 mRNAs were detected, but only poor Cx32 protein expression at cell-cell contact areas was observed in the double transfectants, it is suggested that certain mutants form nonfunctional chimeric connexons with wild-type connexins, which are not properly inserted into the cytoplasmic membrane.
dc:source.dc:creator: Omori Y
dc:source.dc:title: Connexin 32 mutations from X-linked Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease patients: functional defects and dominant negative effects.

evidence.rdfs:label: GJB1 patient derived variants perturb gap junction formation

evidence.dc:description: The authors showed several lines of evidence to indicate that the variants in question altered the ability to form gap junctions, and not as a result of reduced expression or mislocalization. They also tested three variants located in different sections of the GJB1 protein. Due to the abundance of testing, the points awarded were increased from default.

The human GJB1 was shown to be exclusively expressed in  PNS Schwann cells in transgenic animals, expressing the human transgene. No myelination deficits were observed in the Gjb1-/y mice expressing the human GJB1 transgene (rescue), compared to Gjb1-/y mice littermates that showed myelination defects consistent with loss of GJB expression. Furthermore, the rescue mice expressing human GJB1 in the Gjb1-/y mice had prolonged lifespan compared to those mice not expressing the human transgene. Electron micrographs of the hGJB1 rescue mice (in the mouse Gjb1-/Y background) showed rescue of myelination within the femoral nerve (Figure 5), indicating the rescue of myelination.

dc:source.dc:abstract: Mutations in Gap Junction beta1 (GJB1), the gene encoding the gap junction protein connexin32 (Cx32), cause the X-linked form of Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease (CMT1X), an inherited demyelinating neuropathy. We investigated the possibility that the expression of mutant Cx32 in other cells besides myelinating Schwann cells contributes to the development of demyelination. Human Cx32 was expressed in transgenic mice using a rat myelin protein zero (Mpz) promoter, which is exclusively expressed by myelinating Schwann cells. Male mice expressing the human transgene were crossed with female Gjb1/cx32-null mice; the resulting male offspring were all cx32-null (on the X chromosome), and one-half were transgene positive. In these transgenic mice, all of the Cx32 was derived from the expression of the transgene and was found in the sciatic nerve but not in the spinal cord or the liver. Furthermore, the Cx32 protein was properly localized (within incisures and paranodes) in myelinating Schwann cells. Finally, the expression of human Cx32 protein "rescued" the phenotype of cx32-null mice, because the transgenic mice have significantly fewer demyelinated or remyelinated axons than their nontransgenic littermates. These results indicate that the loss of Schwann-cell-autonomous expression of Cx32 is sufficient to account for demyelination in CMT1X.
dc:source.dc:creator: Scherer SS
dc:source.dc:title: Transgenic expression of human connexin32 in myelinating Schwann cells prevents demyelination in connexin32-null mice.

evidence.rdfs:label: Schwann cell directed human GJB1 rescues Gjb1 null mice

evidence.dc:description: Perturbation of GJB1 in humans results in the development of the demyelinating, motor neuropathic Charcot Marie Tooth (CMT) disease. The multiple animal models used here, including GJB1 null mice (Cx32 null/ KO), the T55I patient derived variant, and the R75W patient derived variant all show phenotypes consistent with CMT. Furthermore, the authors go on to show that the T55I is rapidly degraded, thereby functioning similar to a LOF genetic mutation, whilst the R75W variant acts as a dominant negative and can perturb the function wild type Cx32, thus resulting in phenotypes arising in female carriers.

dc:source.dc:abstract: The gap junction (GJ) protein connexin32 (Cx32) is expressed by myelinating Schwann cells and oligodendrocytes and is mutated in X-linked Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease. In addition to a demyelinating peripheral neuropathy, some Cx32 mutants are associated with transient or chronic CNS phenotypes. To investigate the molecular basis of these phenotypes, we generated transgenic mice expressing the T55I or the R75W mutation and an IRES-EGFP, driven by the mouse Cnp promoter. The transgene was expressed in oligodendrocytes throughout the CNS and in Schwann cells. Both the T55I and the R75W mutants were localized in the perinuclear cytoplasm, did not form GJ plaques, and did not alter the expression or localization of two other oligodendrocytic GJ proteins, Cx47 and Cx29, or the expression of Cx29 in Schwann cells. On wild type background, the expression of endogenous mCx32 was unaffected by the T55I mutant, but was partly impaired by R75W. Transgenic mice with the R75W mutation and all mutant animals with Gjb1-null background developed a progressive demyelinating peripheral neuropathy along with CNS myelination defects. These findings suggest that Cx32 mutations result in loss of function in myelinated cells without trans-dominant effects on other GJ proteins. Loss of Cx32 function alone in the CNS causes myelination defects.
dc:source.dc:creator: Sargiannidou I
dc:source.dc:title: Connexin32 mutations cause loss of function in Schwann cells and oligodendrocytes leading to PNS and CNS myelination defects.

evidence.rdfs:label: GJB1 KO mice and expression of T55I and R75W variants

evidence.dc:description: The authors not only studied the GJB1/ Cx32 null mouse, but also expression of the patient derived presumed pathogenic variants T55I and R75W, in either the wild type mouse background or the Gjb1 KO background. They also used a CNS and PNS glial promoter (CNP) to drive expression of the pathogenic variants in both oligodendrocytes and Schwann cells. Therefore, the points were increased from default.

evidence.detectionMethod: Linkage analysis of all families was used to determine that GJB1 was the common gene mutated. Probands and family members had DNA isolated from leukocytes, which was purified, underwent PCR amplification followed by sequencing using SequiTherm. All mutations were confirmed by restriction enzyme digestion.
evidence.previousTestingDescription: Previously tested for duplications of chromosome 17p11.2-p13.

dc:source.dc:abstract: We studied the relationship between the genotype and clinical phenotype in 27 families with dominant X-linked Charcot-Marie-Tooth (CMTX1) neuropathy. Twenty-two families showed mutations in the coding region of the connexin32 (cx32) gene. The mutations include four nonsense mutations, eight missense mutations, two medium size deletions, and one insertion. Most missense mutations showed a mild clinical phenotype (five out of eight), whereas all nonsense mutations, the larger of the two deletions, and the insertion that produced frameshifts showed severe phenotypes. Five CMTX1 families with mild clinical phenotype showed no point mutations of the cx32 gene coding region. Three of these families showed positive genetic linkage with the markers of the Xq13.1 region. The genetic linkage of the remaining two families could not be evaluated because of their small size.
dc:source.dc:creator: Ionasescu V
dc:source.dc:title: Correlation between connexin 32 gene mutations and clinical phenotype in X-linked dominant Charcot-Marie-Tooth neuropathy.

evidence.rdfs:label: Family 6 proband

evidence.dc:description: The E102G variant has been widely studied, and DiVincenzo et al., 2014 PMID: 25614874 indicates that this point mutations is seen in 2.5% of the patients with CMT. The variant alters the voltage dependence of the channel, thus altering its function (Ressot et al., 1998 PMID: 9592087). Furthermore, studies in nude mouse nerve xenografts expressing this variant showed altered axonal integrity consistent with the disease process (PMID: 9469751, 14627639). Therefore, the score has been increased from default.

evidence.detectionMethod: Linkage analysis of all families was used to determine that GJB1 was the common gene mutated. Probands and family members had DNA isolated from leukocytes, which was purified, underwent PCR amplification followed by sequencing using SequiTherm. All mutations were confirmed by restriction enzyme digestion.
evidence.previousTestingDescription: Previously tested for duplications of chromosome 17p11.2-p13.
evidence.rdfs:label: Family 10 proband

evidence.dc:description: Variant Evidence indicates that the R142W variant alters protein trafficking (Deschenes et al., 1997 PMID: 9364054 and VanSlyke et al., 2000 PMID: 10848620) as well as channel formation (Bruzzone et al., 1994, PMID: 7946361), thus the points were increased from default.

evidence.detectionMethod: Linkage analysis of all families was used to determine that GJB1 was the common gene mutated. Probands and family members had DNA isolated from leukocytes, which was purified, underwent PCR amplification followed by sequencing using SequiTherm. All mutations were confirmed by restriction enzyme digestion.
evidence.previousTestingDescription: Previously tested for duplications of chormosome 17p11.2-p13.
evidence.rdfs:label: Family 20 proband

evidence.dc:description: Points were increased, as there are multiple reports of individuals with specific variant, as well as individuals with R146G/Q variants, indicating the R146 as a hotspot for mutation. Furthermore, variant evidence shows  impaired formation and function of the channels using cell voltage clamp recordings (Wang et al., 2004 PMID: 15006706).

evidence.detectionMethod: Genomic DNA was isolated from probands and PCR and SSCP analysis was used to determine the variant in GJB1. Restriction enzyme digestion was used to confirm sequencing results, and co segregation of disease in affected family members.
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: Muscle weakness and atrophy noted as severe. Electrophysiological data noted is as follows: MNC Median Ampl= 0.2 mV, MNC Distal latency= 8.6 ms, MNC conduction velocity= 21 m/s.

dc:source.dc:abstract: Charcot-Marie-Tooth (CMT) disease type CMTX has been linked with mutations in GJB1, a gene on chromosome X coding for a gap junction protein, Connexin 32. We screened the GJB1 gene for mutations by SSCP analysis and sequencing of candidate regions, in five unrelated CMT affected individuals, members of families presenting a mode of transmission and clinical findings compatible with CMTX. Mutations were detected in all five patients. Three not previously reported mutations were identified: C164T, G491A and T359A. Two patients shared the same mutation (C164T) while one had a reported mutation (C43T). Restriction enzyme digestion confirmed the sequencing results, as well as the co-segregation of the mutation with the disease. The same method was used to screen 150 control X chromosomes and the variations were not detected.
dc:source.dc:creator: Karadimas C
dc:source.dc:title: Three novel mutations in the gap junction beta 1 (GJB1) gene coding region identified in Charcot-Marie-Tooth patients of Greek origin: T55I, R164Q, V120E. Mutation in brief no 236. Online.

evidence.rdfs:label: C13

evidence.dc:description: The R15W mutation has been observed in several unrelated individuals indicating a hot spot mutation. Furthermore, the R15W mutation has been shown to perturb the normal function of GJB1 in elecrophysiological assays of conduction strength performed in xenopus oocytes (PMID:11325342). Due to the level of variant evidence to indicate pathogenicity, the points have been increased from default.

evidence.detectionMethod: Linkage analysis of all families was used to determine that GJB1 was the common gene mutated. Probands and family members had DNA isolated from leukocytes, which was purified, underwent PCR amplification followed by sequencing using SequiTherm. All mutations were confirmed by restriction enzyme digestion.
evidence.previousTestingDescription: Previously tested for duplications of chromosome 17p11.2-p13.
evidence.rdfs:label: Family 17 proband

evidence.dc:description: This is a 29 bp deletion that begins at amino acid 265, thus us occurs at the very 3' end of GJB1, in the last exon (2) of GJB1, and would not be expected to undergo nonsense mediated decay. There is no variant evidence to support that this deletion results in abnormal protein function, and thus the default points have been reduced.

evidence.detectionMethod: Genomic DNA was isolated from probands and PCR and SSCP analysis was used to determine the variant in GJB1. Restriction enzyme digestion was used to confirm sequencing results, and co segregation of disease in affected family members.
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: Muscle weakness and atrophy noted as severe. Electrophysiological data noted is as follows: MNC Median Ampl= 0.6 mV, MNC Distal latency= 46.6 ms, MNC conduction velocity= 29 m/s.
evidence.rdfs:label: C12

evidence.dc:description: The T55I mutation has been observed in several unrelated individuals indicating a hot spot mutation. Furthermore, the T55I mutation has been shown to perturb the normal function of GJB1 in both cellular assays (PMID:9364054, 9592087, 10848620, 15006706) and when expressed in a model organism (mouse model) it caused development of peripheral neuropathy consistent with Charcot Marie Tooth (PMID: 19369543). Due to the level of variant evidence to indicate pathogenicity, the points have been increased from default.

evidence.detectionMethod: Linkage analysis of all families was used to determine that GJB1 was the common gene mutated. Probands and family members had DNA isolated from leukocytes, which was purified, underwent PCR amplification followed by sequencing using SequiTherm. All mutations were confirmed by restriction enzyme digestion.
evidence.previousTestingDescription: Previously tested for duplications of chromosome 17p11.2-p13.
evidence.rdfs:label: Family 15-1

evidence.dc:description: Given that GJB1 has only 2 exons, and the cysteine 217 is in exon 2, this termination variant may not undergo nonsense mediated decay. No variant evidence has been published, thus the score has been downgraded.

evidence.detectionMethod: Genomic DNA was isolated from probands and PCR and SSCP analysis was used to determine the variant in GJB1. Restriction enzyme digestion was used to confirm sequencing results, and co segregation of disease in affected family members.
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: Muscle weakness and atrophy noted as severe. Electrophysiological data noted is as follows: MNC Median Ampl= 0.8 mV, MNC Distal latency= 4.4 ms, MNC conduction velocity= 33 m/s.
evidence.rdfs:label: C2

evidence.dc:description: The T55I mutation has been observed in several unrelated individuals indicating a hot spot mutation. Furthermore, the T55I mutation has been shown to perturb the normal function of GJB1 in both cellular assays (PMID:9364054, 9592087, 10848620, 15006706) and when expressed in a model organism (mouse model) it caused development of peripheral neuropathy consistent with Charcot Marie Tooth (PMID: 19369543). Due to the level of variant evidence to indicate pathogenicity, the points have been increased from default.

evidence.detectionMethod: Linkage analysis of all families was used to determine that GJB1 was the common gene mutated. Probands and family members had DNA isolated from leukocytes, which was purified, underwent PCR amplification followed by sequencing using SequiTherm. All mutations were confirmed by restriction enzyme digestion.
evidence.previousTestingDescription: Previously tested for duplications of chormosome 17p11.2-p13.
evidence.rdfs:label: Family 1-1

evidence.dc:description: Proband is also published in PMID:11571214 (Dubourg et al., 2001). This mutation has been found in a female with reported CMT, that was indicated to have a de novo mutation (PMID: 21692908), however the authors did not indicate that the parents were genetically tested and found negative. The presence of two, presumably un related individuals with the same mutation indicates a hotspot, and while the mutation may not cause nonsense mediated decay, it is likely to severely disrupt the function of GJB1. Thus, the default score for a loss of function variant was awarded.

evidence.detectionMethod: Blood samples obtained from the proband, the proband's mother, and the proban'ds two siblings (2 brothers and 1 sister). Genomic DNA was isolated from all members stated above, and PCR-SSCP analysis was used to identify the mutation in GJB1. The proband's father had died at the age of 68 from lung carcinoma and was not available for testing, however this is an X-linked condition and therefore would not be inherited from the father.
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: the areflexia was noted as deep tendon. Phenotypes were first noted for weakness in childhood. Electrophysiology showed a motor nerve conduction (MNCV) in the right and left median nerves of 35 and 34m/s, respectively, and in the left ulnar and right peroneal nerve of 40 and 34 m/s, respectively. A noted compound muscle action potential amplitude of 6mV (left unlar) and 0.06mV (right peroneal) was recorded. A severely reduced left senosry action potential was noted, at 2.2uV. No response recorded from the sural nerve. Sural nerve biopsy indicated a demyelinating neuropathy with onion bulb formations.
evidence.previousTestingDescription: Proband was tested for PMP2 and MPZ (myelin protein zero) mutations and found negative.

dc:source.dc:abstract: We report a 26-year-old Italian man with X-linked Charcot-Marie-Tooth (CMT) disease type 1 (CMT-X1) and a negative family history for neuromuscular diseases. Clinical and electrophysiological examinations of the patient's mother and siblings were normal. Molecular analysis by polymerase chain reaction--single-strand conformation polymorphism (PCR-SSCP) on genomic DNA from the patient and all members of his family revealed a C-to-T transition in codon 8 of exon 2 of the connexin-32 (Cx32) gene on the X chromosome only in the patient. This transition in the 5'-coding region, resulting in a Thr-Ile substitution, is likely to be the cause of CMT phenotype in our patient, and it represents a new de novo mutation of the Cx32 gene.
dc:source.dc:creator: Di Iorio G
dc:source.dc:title: A new de novo mutation of the connexin-32 gene in a patient with X-linked Charcot-Marie-Tooth type 1 disease.

evidence.rdfs:label: Di-Iorio proband 1

evidence.dc:description: While the proband has a confirmed de novo mutation in GJB1, the variant is a missense variant (Thr8Ile), and there is not variant evidence to support that the mutation perturbs the normal function of GJB1. Of note, Thr8 has been showed to be mutated with an alternative amino acid (Thr8Pro) in an proband diagnosed with Charcot Marie Tooth, indicating a hotspot. Lack of supporting, functional variant evidence, resulted in a reduction from the default points.

dc:description:
GJB1 was first reported in relation to Charcot Marie Tooth (CMT) disease in 1993 (Bergoffen et al., 1993; PMID: 8266101) At least 450 unique variants, including missense, nonsense, frameshift, and indels have been reported in humans (reviewed in Bortolozzi, 2018; PMID: 30042657; Kleopa et al., 2012; PMID: 22771394). There are a variant databases describing GJB1 variants of interest in CMT, and include (1) the Inherited Neuropathy Variant Database (greater than 700 GJB1 variants; URL: http://hihg.med.miami.edu/code/http/cmt/public_html/index.html#/), and (2) the GJB1 Gene homepage on LOVD (URL: https://databases.lovd.nl/shared/genes/GJB1). Evidence supporting this gene-disease relationship includes case-level data and experimental data. This gene-disease relationship has been studied for over 20 years, therefore a significant amount of case-level data and segregation is available, however the maximum score for genetic evidence (12 points) has been reached. This gene-disease relationship is supported by expression studies and animal models. 
GJB1 has 2 exons of which the entirety of the protein coding region is encoded by exon 2, therefore nonsense variants are not predicted to undergo nonsense mediated decay. The molecular mechanism associated with CMT is loss of functional gap junction function, including destabilization or loss of hetero- and homo-dimerization with connexins, and perturbation of ion and small molecule exchange across the multilamellar layers of myelin sheath (reviewed in Scherer and Wrabetz, 2008; PMID:  18803325;  Nualart-Marti et al., 2013; PMID: 22326946). In summary, GJB1 is DEFINITIVELY associated with x-linked Charcot Marie Tooth disease. This has been repeatedly demonstrated in both the research and clinical diagnostic settings, and has been upheld over time. This classification was approved by the ClinGen Charcot Marie Tooth Gene Curation Expert Panel on Jan 14, 2020.
